data.title: Robert Burns and Russia
data.meta_description: Robert Burns also known familiarly as Rabbie Burns, was a Scottish poet and lyricist. He is regarded as the national poet of Scotland and is celebrated worldwide. Burns became the "people's poet" of Russia. He was translated into Russian and became a source of inspiration for the ordinary, oppressed Russian people.
data.text:
Haggis. A regular visitor to family meals during my childhood living in Scotland.

While at University, on rather tight finances, after rent and booze bills were taken care of, noodles or peanut butter sandwiches were not on our budget conscious menu. Rather we would troop out to Iceland and pick up a dozen frozen haggis. Microwaved they were brilliant. Very filling, great mouth feel (chewy bits), plenty of greasy goodness, totally satisfying. Throw in some mashed tatties and a big dollop of coarse mashed neeps, and you have a great meal that verges on healthy.

Regardless of how often or how little haggis was consumed in any given year, there was one day that we were guaranteed to serve haggis, neeps and tatties: Rabbie Burns Night on the 25th of January.

Of course some poor soul had to address the haggis with Robert Burn's famous tongue-in-cheek poem "Address to a Haggis" before cutting it open. The favourite verse of youngsters being, naturally,

"His knife see rustic Labour dight,

An cut you up wi ready slight,

Trenching your gushing entrails bright,

Like onie ditch;

And then, O what a glorious sight,

Warm-reekin, rich!"

I admit to being surprised anybody had even heard of the bard of my homeland outside of Scotland. So I did a bit of research. Here's what I found:

Robert Burns (25 January 1759  21 July 1796), also known familiarly as Rabbie Burns, the National Bard, Bard of Ayrshire, the Ploughman Poet and various other names and epithets, was a Scottish poet and lyricist. He is widely regarded as the national poet of Scotland and is celebrated worldwide.
